learning_outcomes.description: Relate the structure and properties of food components to their functional and chemical properties.
Demonstrate a sound knowledge of the integrated behaviour of food systems.
Describe different procedures used for food analysis.

Work individually or as part of a team to illustrate how lab techniques could be used to solve experimental problems involving the accurate quantification and characterisation of the physical and chemical properties of food and beverages.
Communicate experimental results of food analyses in written form.

assessments.task_description:
Only material from the Tutorials, Water, Carbohydrates I and II, Amino acids and Proteins, Food Enzymes, and Lipids I lecture will be examined.

Students will have 10 minutes planning time, followed by 60 minutes to complete the exam.

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.  

Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.weighting: <dd>40% Each Practical Quiz contributes 10% to the overall weighting of 40% </dd>

Practical 4 Quiz Due date 22/05/2026 2:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
The Practical Knowledge Assessments are short, structured quizzes designed to evaluate students’ understanding of the chemical principles, experimental methods, and data interpretation associated with each laboratory practical in food chemistry. The quizzes assess both conceptual knowledge and applied analytical skills, ensuring alignment with the learning outcomes of the practical sessions.

Each quiz may include a combination of multiple-choice questions, fill-in-the-blank questions, and calculation-based questions. Calculation questions require students to interpret experimental data provided in the quiz or generated during the corresponding laboratory session, using appropriate units, significant figures, and chemical reasoning.

For selected experiments, students will be required to upload an image or digital file of their calibration curve or experimental data plots, such as standard curves or reaction profiles. These submissions assess students’ ability to correctly construct, present, and interpret analytical data.

All quizzes are completed individually and are designed to support the development of core quantitative and data interpretation skills essential in food chemistry.

  • Prac 1 Quiz opens on Friday 14:00 Week 7, due date Friday 14:00 Week 8
  • Prac 2 Quiz opens on Friday 14:00 Week 9, due date Friday 14:00 Week 10
  • Prac 3 Quiz opens on Friday 14:00 Week 10, due date Friday 14:00 Week 11
  • Prac 4 Quiz opens on Friday 14:00 Week 11, due date Friday 14:00 Week 12


To obtain a mark for the practical classes, students must participate and complete the associated exercises (completing the quiz via Blackboard). If you do not participate in a practical class, or do not provide evidence of your attendance (i.e. signing the attendance sheet), your quiz will not be graded. Refer to late submission notes for more information. 

Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. 

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Contact AskUs immediately: support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you. 


Laboratory practical class attendance.

Students are required to attend the practical each week to complete the practical and the practical quiz. To obtain a grade for the quiz associated with a particular practical class, students must attend and complete the associated experiments. If you do not attend a practical class or do not provide evidence of your attendance (i.e. signing the attendance sheet), your quiz for that particular practical will not be marked/graded.

Students who cannot attend a practical due to medical reasons, accident, bereavement, jury service and other circumstances allowed in the UQ Policies and Procedures Library (PPL) should apply for a Practical Absence (refer to Task Description for Practical Quizzes).

Practical attendance and punctuality

Students are required to arrive on time and be present for the pre-laboratory briefing, safety instructions, and explanation of experimental procedures. For safety, equity, and disruption-minimisation reasons, students who arrive more than 15 minutes after the scheduled start time will not be permitted to enter the laboratory or participate in the practical session. Late arrival compromises safety briefings and disrupts laboratory workflows.

Students who are unable to attend a practical session or who arrive too late to be admitted must follow the University’s procedures for absence and apply for consideration in accordance with University policy.

Absence from a Practical Session 

If you are unable to complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation.  

A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting documentation is found at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1  

Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of the missed practical. The submission link can be found in the Learning Resources (Blackboard Original) or Course Resources (Blackboard Ultra) folder in your course Blackboard site.  

Requests without the correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered absent from that practical session.  

It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation.  

If there is an associated assessment item, you must submit the relevant assessment item by the due date. If the reason for your absence impacts your ability to meet the due date, you must apply for an extension of assessment due date.  

If you require access to restricted online resources such as videos to complete your assessment, you must contact the course coordinator to get access to the online resources.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Practical Knowledge Assessments are completed online via Blackboard within the specified availability window.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Food Chemistry Lectures

Contains lectures on the structure and functions of food components and systems. Reactions and interactions of food components, particularly related to degradative processes.

Introduction to the chemical analysis of foods using modern analytical chemistry techniques.

Readings/Ref: Blackboard; Library website


Sub-activity: Water; Carbohydrates; Amino acids and proteins; Food enzymes; Lipids; Introduction to food analysis; Browning; Vitamins and minerals; Colour; and Flavour chemistry

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Food Chemistry Lectures Contains lectures on the structure and functions of food components and systems. Reactions and interactions of food components, particularly related to degradative processes. Introduction to the chemical analysis of foods using modern analytical chemistry techniques. Readings/Ref: Blackboard; Library website Sub-activity: Water; Carbohydrates; Amino acids and proteins; Food enzymes; Lipids; Introduction to food analysis; Browning; Vitamins and minerals; Colour; and Flavour chemistry
